text.headline: Turing Test Proposed
text.text: Alan Turing publishes 'Computing Machinery and Intelligence,' proposing the Turing Test as a measure of machine intelligence.

events.notes: This foundational paper asked 'Can machines think?' and established criteria for evaluating machine intelligence that remains influential today.

text.headline: Birth of AI Field
text.text: Dartmouth Conference coins the term 'Artificial Intelligence' with John McCarthy, Marvin Minsky, and other pioneers.

events.notes: This conference is considered the birth of AI as a distinct field of study, bringing together researchers who would shape the field for decades.

text.headline: Perceptron Algorithm
text.text: Frank Rosenblatt develops the Perceptron algorithm, an early neural network that could learn from examples.

events.notes: The Perceptron was one of the first algorithms capable of learning, laying groundwork for modern neural networks despite its limitations.

text.headline: ELIZA Chatbot Created
text.text: Joseph Weizenbaum creates ELIZA, an early chatbot using pattern matching to simulate conversation.

events.notes: ELIZA demonstrated that simple pattern matching could create surprisingly convincing conversational interactions, though it had no true understanding.

text.headline: First AI Winter
text.text: Period of reduced funding and interest in AI due to unmet expectations and limited computational power.

events.notes: Overpromising and underdelivering led to reduced funding and skepticism about AI's potential, slowing progress for a decade.

text.headline: Expert Systems Boom
text.text: Rule-based AI systems gain commercial success, with expert systems deployed in specialized domains like medical diagnosis.

events.notes: Expert systems like MYCIN and DENDRAL showed practical applications of AI, encoding human expertise as rules and inference engines.

text.headline: Second AI Winter
text.text: Expert systems limitations and hardware constraints lead to another period of reduced AI investment.

events.notes: The brittleness of expert systems, high maintenance costs, and hardware limitations led to disillusionment and another funding contraction.

text.headline: Deep Blue Defeats Kasparov
text.text: IBM's Deep Blue defeats world chess champion Garry Kasparov, demonstrating AI's capability in complex strategic games.

events.notes: This milestone showed that AI could match human expertise in highly complex domains, though through brute-force search rather than human-like reasoning.

text.headline: Deep Learning Revival
text.text: Geoffrey Hinton and colleagues achieve breakthroughs in training deep neural networks, revitalizing neural network research.

events.notes: Hinton's work on restricted Boltzmann machines and deep belief networks showed how to train networks with many layers, overcoming previous limitations.

text.headline: IBM Watson Wins Jeopardy!
text.text: IBM Watson defeats human champions at Jeopardy! using natural language processing and machine learning.

events.notes: Watson demonstrated sophisticated natural language understanding, combining multiple AI techniques to interpret questions and generate answers.

text.headline: AlexNet Deep Learning Breakthrough
text.text: AlexNet wins ImageNet competition using deep convolutional neural networks, sparking the modern deep learning revolution.

events.notes: AlexNet's dramatic performance improvement showed the power of deep CNNs trained on GPUs with large datasets, transforming computer vision.

text.headline: GANs Introduced
text.text: Ian Goodfellow introduces Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs), enabling realistic image and data generation.

events.notes: GANs revolutionized generative modeling by pitting two neural networks against each other, leading to unprecedented realism in generated content.

text.headline: Transformer Architecture
text.text: Google researchers publish 'Attention Is All You Need,' introducing the transformer architecture that powers modern LLMs.

events.notes: The transformer architecture with self-attention mechanisms enabled parallelized training and better handling of long-range dependencies in sequences.

text.headline: BERT Released
text.text: Google releases BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers), advancing NLP with bidirectional context understanding.

events.notes: BERT's bidirectional training enabled deeper understanding of context by considering both left and right context simultaneously, improving many NLP tasks.

text.headline: GPT-3 Demonstrates Few-Shot Learning
text.text: OpenAI releases GPT-3 with 175 billion parameters, demonstrating impressive few-shot learning capabilities.

events.notes: GPT-3's scale enabled emergent capabilities like few-shot learning, where the model could perform new tasks from just a few examples without fine-tuning.

text.headline: ChatGPT Launches
text.text: OpenAI releases ChatGPT, bringing conversational AI to mainstream adoption with millions of users.

events.notes: ChatGPT's intuitive interface and impressive capabilities made advanced AI accessible to the general public, accelerating AI adoption across industries.

text.headline: GPT-4 and Multimodal Models
text.text: GPT-4 and competing models achieve multimodal capabilities, processing both text and images.

events.notes: Multimodal models expanded AI capabilities beyond text to handle images, audio, and video, enabling more versatile applications.

text.headline: Enterprise AI Adoption
text.text: Widespread enterprise adoption of conversational AI and RAG (Retrieval Augmented Generation) systems.

events.notes: Organizations integrate LLMs with their proprietary data using RAG patterns, enabling AI assistants with domain-specific knowledge.
